questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of chest pain that begins after walking at a brisk pace for 2 blocks. The pain does not radiate anywhere and is hard to localize. He has had similar episodes in the past 6 months and was prescribed sublingual nitroglycerin, which helps relieve the pain. The patient has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He takes lisinopril and metformin daily. He appears well. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min and regular, and blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. S1 and S2 are normal. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There is no peripheral edema. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the improvement of this patient's chest pain?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nitroglycerin has no effect on electrical conduction. Reducing the electrical conduction speed, and thus heart rate is a mechanism to achieve a long-term reduction of myocardial oxygen demand. It can be achieved by various drugs, metoprolol being one of the most common ones. In later stages that are refractory to common treatment, ranolazine can be added to target late inward sodium channels within myocardial tissue and provide relief in some cases of chronic angina.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased venous pooling can result from the use of compression stockings or sympathomimetic drugs that cause vasoconstriction of arteriolar and venous vasculature. This increases venous return and therefore cardiac preload, which in turn increases myocardial wall tension and reduces myocardial perfusion. Nitroglycerin has the opposite effect: smooth muscle relaxation, mainly of the venous vessels, leads to venodilation and subsequent increased blood pooling in the venous system.

C) INCORRECT:

Nitroglycerin causes both peripheral and coronary arterial vasodilation. However, this drug predominantly targets the venous system and coronary dilation is not the primary mechanism of improving myocardial perfusion. In angina, the coronary arteries are typically in a chronic state of dilation in an attempt to preserve perfusion of the myocardial tissue (decreased coronary reserve). In these cases, nitroglycerin provides only a minimal increase in blood flow to the coronary arteries but can still achieve symptom relief via a different mechanism.

D) INCORRECT:

Peripheral arterial vasodilation is one of the effects of nitroglycerin. It results in decreased afterload, which in turn decreases myocardial oxygen demand to a certain extent. However, there is another, much more prominent nitroglycerin-mediated mechanism that is more likely to reduce this patient's symptoms. Arterial vasodilation is the primary effect of calcium channel blockers, not that of nitroglycerin.

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased ventricular compliance occurs most commonly in ventricular hypertrophy (LVH or RVH) and any type of restrictive cardiomyopathy. Nitroglycerin actually improves ventricular compliance through reduced myocardial wall tension.

F) INCORRECT:

Increased atherosclerotic plaque stability is achieved with statins (e.g., atorvastatin, rosuvastatin). While this patient may benefit from statin therapy, this medication would not have any effect on his current chest pain.

G) CORRECT:

Nitrates, such as nitroglycerin, cause arterial and venous vasodilation by inducing smooth muscle relaxation. Anginal pain relief is mainly achieved by venous dilation (venous pooling), which leads to decreased end-diastolic pressure (i.e., decreased preload), reduced myocardial wall tension, and improved myocardial perfusion. The decreased preload results in reduced heart size and decreased myocardial oxygen demand. To a lesser degree, nitrates decrease afterload by triggering arterial vasodilation, thus reducing myocardial contraction effort and oxygen demand. Because the coronary arteries are already fully dilated in patients with CAD in an attempt to provide as much oxygen to cardiac tissue as possible, the effect of nitrates on these vessels is limited.

Life-threatening hypotension may occur if nitrates are taken within 24 hours of a PDE-5 inhibitor such as sildenafil.
Image Description:

Exogenous nitrous oxide (NO) activates guanylyl cyclase, resulting in activation of protein kinase G. There is a reduction in intracellular calcium as a result of increased sarcoplasmic reticulum calcium ATPase (SERCA) and an increase in myosin-light-chain-phosphatase (MLCP) activity, resulting in smooth muscle relaxation. The net result of both pathways is vasodilation.
questions.hint: This patient's exertional chest pain relieved by nitroglycerin indicates angina pectoris due to coronary artery disease (CAD), which is consistent with his history of the risk factors hypertension and diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with hypertension and hyperlipidemia comes to the physician because of a 10-month history of substernal chest pain on exertion that is relieved with rest. His pulse is 82/min and blood pressure is 145/82 mm Hg. He is prescribed a drug that acts by forming free radical nitric oxide. The patient is most likely to experience which of the following adverse effects as a result of this drug?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Headaches are a common side effect of nitrates and affect approx. 10% of patients. These headaches are either mild-to-moderate and occur immediately after drug administration (due to nitric oxide-induced vasodilation) or migraine-like, occurring several hours after drug intake (due to nitric oxide-mediated release of neurotransmitters such as calcitonin gene-related peptide and glutamate, and/or altered ion channel function). Nitrate-induced vasodilation decreases both preload and afterload and improves myocardial perfusion, but may also result in cutaneous flushing and hypotension.

Other adverse effects include gastroesophageal reflux and reflex tachycardia, the latter of which can be treated with beta blockers.

B) INCORRECT:

Digital vasospasm (secondary Raynaud phenomenon) is a potential side effect of beta blockers. This side effect is mediated by the blockade of β2-receptors, which causes vasoconstriction. Nitrates do not cause digital vasospasm.

C) INCORRECT:

Nitrates can cause hypotension, rather than hypertensive urgency. Nitrates are used to treat hypertensive crisis for short-term reduction of blood pressure and are contraindicated in hypotensive patients.

D) INCORRECT:

Nonproductive cough is a side effect of ACE inhibitors. This side effect is due to decreased breakdown of bradykinin, which increases production of arachidonic acid metabolites (e.g., prostaglandins). The accumulation of prostaglandins in the upper respiratory tract and the lungs results in nonproductive cough. Nitrates do not cause cough.

E) INCORRECT:

Lupus-like syndrome (drug-induced lupus erythematosus; DILE) is a side effect of antihypertensives, such as hydralazine and methyldopa. Other drugs that can lead to DILE include monoclonal TNF-α inhibitors, such as infliximab or etanercept, procainamide, penicillamine, isoniazid, minocycline, and phenytoin. Nitrates do not cause DILE.

F) INCORRECT:

Lower extremity edema is a common side effect of dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (CCBs), particularly amlodipine. CCBs cause vasodilation, which increases the hydrostatic pressure within the blood vessels, causing extravasation of plasma into the interstitial space. Although nitrates can rarely cause lower extremity edema, it is not the most common side effect associated with this drug class.

G) INCORRECT:

Erectile dysfunction is a known side effect of beta blockers, which inhibit β2-receptors in the vasculature and thereby cause vasoconstriction. Patients taking PDE-5 inhibitors for erectile dysfunction have an increased risk of life-threatening hypotension if nitrates are taken within 24 hours of a PDE-5 inhibitor. Nitrates do not cause erectile dysfunction.
questions.hint: Nitrates work by forming free radical nitric oxide, which leads to smooth muscle relaxation and vasodilation.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with stable coronary artery disease comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Aside from occasional exertional chest pain on mowing the lawn or prolonged jogging, he feels well. He goes jogging for 20 minutes once a week and takes a tablet of sublingual nitroglycerine prior to his run to prevent anginal chest pain. The patient would like to run longer distances and asks the physician whether he could increase the dose of the drug prior to running. Administration of higher dosages of this drug is most likely to result in which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rebound angina is the increase in anginal symptoms due to decreased drug levels during the nitrate-free intervals in intermittent therapy. It is usually associated with the use of transdermal nitroglycerin patches, not with sublingual administration. Moreover, this patient's once-weekly usage puts him at low risk for rebound angina.

B) INCORRECT:

Nitrate tolerance often develops after 2–3 days of continuous administration and is more likely with high dosages and long-acting preparations. In order to minimize this side effect, daily nitrate-free intervals of at least 8 hours are recommended. Since this patient only has an estimated once-weekly usage with adequate medication-free intervals, a higher dosage will not increase his risk of developing tolerance.

C) CORRECT:

Low-dose nitrate improves myocardial perfusion primarily by acting as a venodilator that decreases ventricular wall tension via preload reduction. In addition, high-dose nitrate dilates coronary and peripheral arteries, thereby preventing coronary spasms and reducing ventricular afterload along with subsequent myocardial oxygen demand. However, peripheral arterial dilation also causes systemic hypotension, which induces a reflex sympathetic activity leading to tachycardia and increased myocardial contractility. As a result, myocardial oxygen demand paradoxically increases. Simultaneous administration of β-blockers has a synergetic anti-ischemic effect and can help prevent reflex tachycardia.

D) INCORRECT:

Anaphylactic reactions occur in < 1% of patients treated with nitrates. Furthermore, this patient has been taking this drug regularly, making an allergic reaction to an increase in dosage unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Nitrates dilate coronary arteries and thus prevent rather than cause coronary artery spasms. Therefore, they are regularly used in the long-term treatment of Prinzmetal angina.

F) INCORRECT:

Symptoms of withdrawal can occur after abrupt cessation of use of an addictive recreational or therapeutic substance. Nitrates are not known to cause addiction.
questions.hint: Administration of metoprolol would help to counteract this adverse effect.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician because of worsening chest pain on exertion. She was diagnosed with coronary artery disease and hyperlipidemia 3 months ago. At the time of diagnosis, she was able to walk for 15 minutes on the treadmill until the onset of chest pain. Her endurance had improved temporarily after she began medical treatment and she was able to walk her dog for 30 minutes daily without experiencing chest pain. Her current medications include daily aspirin, metoprolol, atorvastatin, and isosorbide dinitrate four times daily. Her pulse is 55/min and blood pressure is 115/78 mm Hg. Treadmill walking test shows an onset of chest pain after 18 minutes. Which of the following is most likely to improve this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Beta-blockers such as metoprolol are a first-line therapy for stable angina, as their effect of lowering heart rate and contractility reduces ischemia. However, this patient already has a low heart rate, indicating that metoprolol is still effective. Increasing the metoprolol dose further could cause hemodynamic instability.

B) CORRECT:

Development of nitrate tolerance leading to decreased drug effectiveness is a typical side effect of long-term therapy. The underlying mechanism is not completely understood but is thought to involve decreased sensitivity of the vascular endothelium to nitrates. The most effective strategy to prevent nitrate tolerance is intermittent therapy with nitrate-free intervals of at least 8 hours, which would be accomplished by avoiding isosorbide dinitrate at night.

C) INCORRECT:

Statins are commonly used in the treatment of both hyperlipidemia and coronary artery disease. Discontinuation may be necessary in the setting of intolerable side effects or statin-induced myopathy which would present with symptoms of muscle pain and weakness. This patient, however, is experiencing drug tolerance, not drug toxicity.

D) INCORRECT:

Phosphodiesterase type-5 inhibitors such as tadalafil are contraindicated in patients taking nitrates because the synergistic vasodilation can result in extreme hypotension and syncope. Furthermore, tadalafil is indicated for the treatment of erectile dysfunction, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and pulmonary hypertension but not angina pectoris.

E) INCORRECT:

Invasive tests such as coronary angiography are reserved for patients with stable angina who are refractory to optimal medical management or belong to a high-risk demographic. This patient's symptoms improved after initial pharmacotherapy and then worsened again, which indicates drug tolerance. Hence, medical therapy should be adjusted first. Furthermore, angiography alone would not treat this patient's symptoms since it is a diagnostic test.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with stable angina pectoris should be encouraged to engage in regular aerobic exercise, since this can result in a lower oxygen requirement of the myocardium for a given workload, thereby improving exercise tolerance and reducing symptoms. Furthermore, this patient's 15-minute exercise tolerance has improved since initiating medical therapy, which indicates that she still has adequate aerobic exercise capacity.
questions.hint: This patient experiences stable anginal chest pain that initially improved with medication before worsening again. This decline in the effectiveness of medication likely occurred due to drug tolerance.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination of diffuse exertional chest pain which he has successfully been treating with sublingual nitroglycerin for the past year. The patient has been taking lisinopril daily for essential hypertension. His pulse is 75/min and regular, and blood pressure is 155/90 mm Hg. Cardiac and pulmonary examination show no abnormalities; there is no peripheral edema. A decrease of which of the following is the most likely explanation for the improvement of this patient's chest pain?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ventricular compliance describes the volume/fluid moved for a given change in pressure (C = ΔV/ΔP). It thus decreases in ventricular hypertrophy (increased pressure, with no change in volume moved) or any type of restrictive cardiomyopathy (pressure stays the same, volume decreases). Nitroglycerin actually improves ventricular compliance by reduction of myocardial preload and its effects.

B) INCORRECT:

The decrease in peripheral arterial resistance is achieved through arterial vasodilation, which is one of the effects of nitroglycerin. It results in decreased afterload, which in turn decreases myocardial oxygen demand to a certain extent. However, there is another, much more prominent nitroglycerin-mediated mechanism that is more likely to reduce this patient's symptoms. Arterial vasodilation is the primary effect of calcium channel blockers, not that of nitroglycerin.

C) INCORRECT:

Nitroglycerin has no effect on electrical conduction. Reducing the electrical conduction speed, and thus heart rate, is a mechanism to achieve a long-term reduction of myocardial oxygen demand. It can be achieved by various drugs, metoprolol being one of the most common ones. In later stages that are refractory to common treatment, ranolazine can be added to target late inward sodium channels within myocardial tissue and provide relief in some cases of chronic angina.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased venous pooling can result from the use of compression stockings or sympathomimetic drugs that cause vasoconstriction of arteriolar and venous vasculature. This increases venous return and therefore cardiac preload, which in turn increases myocardial wall tension and reduces myocardial perfusion. Nitroglycerin has the opposite effect: Smooth muscle relaxation, mainly of the venous vessels, leads to venodilation and subsequent increased blood pooling in the venous system.

E) INCORRECT:

Nitroglycerin does cause coronary arterial vasodilation, in addition to vasodilation throughout the body. However, nitroglycerin predominantly targets the venous system and coronary dilation is not the primary mechanism of improving myocardial perfusion. In angina, the coronary arteries are typically in a chronic state of dilation in an attempt to preserve perfusion of the myocardial tissue (= decreased coronary reserve). In these cases, nitroglycerin provides no additional increase in blood flow to the coronary arteries but can still achieve symptom relief via a different mechanism.

Nitrates are also used in the treatment of coronary artery spasm (via muscle relaxation) in vasospastic angina.

F) CORRECT:

The administration of nitroglycerin causes smooth muscle relaxation in the vascular system, predominantly in the venous system. It thus increases venous pooling which subsequently decreases myocardial preload. This results in a decreased end-diastolic pressure, which decreases myocardial wall tension and thus improves myocardial perfusion while decreasing myocardial oxygen demand. The shift towards a more favorable ratio of perfusion to demand is the primary mechanism through which symptom relief is achieved.
Image Description:

Exogenous nitrous oxide (NO) activates guanylyl cyclase, resulting in activation of protein kinase G. There is a reduction in intracellular calcium as a result of increased sarcoplasmic reticulum calcium ATPase (SERCA) and an increase in myosin-light-chain-phosphatase (MLCP) activity, resulting in smooth muscle relaxation. The net result of both pathways is vasodilation.
questions.hint: Exertional chest pain in this patient is likely caused by angina pectoris, a chest pain that occurs if myocardial oxygen demand cannot be met due to coronary heart disease. Nitroglycerin dilates smooth muscle cells in both arteries and veins, which in turn reduces myocardial preload, decreases myocardial oxygen demand, and subsequently provides symptom relief.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old former smoker with a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and stable coronary artery disease wants to discuss options for treating erectile dysfunction. He reports progressive inability to maintain an erection for the duration of intercourse. He states that his brother had similar symptoms that are satisfactorily managed with tadalafil, and he would like to try it himself.
The patient’s current medications are insulin glargine, metformin, metoprolol, isosorbide mononitrate, irbesartan, and hydrochlorothiazide.
Which one of the following treatments for this patient’s erectile dysfunction is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE-5) inhibitors, such as vardenafil, are considered first-line treatment for erectile dysfunction. These medications increase penile cyclic guanosine monophosphate and induce relaxation of penile smooth muscle. In this patient who is taking a nitrate (isosorbide), PDE-5 inhibitors are contraindicated because severe hypotension can occur. If this patient were not taking isosorbide, his other medications would not be contraindications to use of a PDE-5 inhibitor.

B) INCORRECT:

Phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE-5) inhibitors, such as tadalafil, are considered first-line treatment for erectile dysfunction. These medications increase penile cyclic guanosine monophosphate and induce relaxation of penile smooth muscle. In this patient who is taking a nitrate (isosorbide), PDE-5 inhibitors are contraindicated because severe hypotension can occur. If this patient were not taking isosorbide, his other medications would not be contraindications to use of a PDE-5 inhibitor.

C) CORRECT:

Erectile dysfunction, defined as the inability to consistently achieve or sustain a penile erection to permit satisfactory sexual intercourse, is a common concern as men age. This patient has several risk factors for erectile dysfunction: type 2 diabetes, coronary artery disease, a history of cigarette smoking, and antihypertensive medication use. Other risk factors are benign prostatic hyperplasia, hypogonadism and other endocrine disorders, central nervous system disease, spinal cord injury, depression, and marital stress.

Phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE-5) inhibitors, such as tadalafil, sildenafil, and vardenafil, are considered first-line treatment for erectile dysfunction. These medications increase penile cyclic guanosine monophosphate and induce relaxation of penile smooth muscle. In this patient who is taking a nitrate (isosorbide), PDE-5 inhibitors are contraindicated because severe hypotension can occur. If this patient were not taking isosorbide, his other medications would not be contraindications to use of a PDE-5 inhibitor.

Vacuum erection devices and penile prosthetic devices can be used in patients in whom a PDE-5 inhibitor is contraindicated. Vacuum devices, which confer lower risk than penile implants, are the preferred option for managing this patient’s erectile dysfunction. Another acceptable alternative would be intraurethral administration of alprostadil.

Key learning point: Because of the risk for severe hypotension, a phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitor should not be used in men who are already taking a nitrate medication.

D) INCORRECT:

Tamsulosin is indicated for benign prostatic hyperplasia and for some patients with nephrolithiasis. It has no role in the management of erectile dysfunction.

E) INCORRECT:

Testosterone replacement is not indicated in a patient without documented hypogonadism.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with hypertension and hyperlipidemia comes to the physician because of a 10-month history of substernal chest pain on exertion that is relieved with rest. His pulse is 82/min and blood pressure is 145/82 mm Hg. He is prescribed a drug that acts by forming free radical nitric oxide. The patient is most likely to experience which of the following adverse effects as a result of this drug?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Headaches are a common side effect of nitrates and affect approx. 10% of patients. These headaches are either mild-to-moderate and occur immediately after drug administration (due to nitric oxide-induced vasodilation) or migraine-like, occurring several hours after drug intake (due to nitric oxide-mediated release of neurotransmitters such as calcitonin gene-related peptide and glutamate, and/or altered ion channel function). Other adverse effects include gastroesophageal reflux and reflex tachycardia, the latter of which can be treated with beta blockers.

Digital vasospasm (secondary Raynaud phenomenon) is a potential side effect of beta blockers. This side effect is mediated by the blockade of β2-receptors, which causes vasoconstriction. Nitrates do not cause digital vasospasm.

C) INCORRECT:

Nonproductive cough is a side effect of ACE inhibitors. This side effect is due to decreased breakdown of bradykinin, which increases production of arachidonic acid metabolites (e.g., prostaglandins). The accumulation of prostaglandins in the upper respiratory tract and the lungs results in nonproductive cough. Nitrates do not cause cough.

Lupus-like syndrome (drug-induced lupus erythematosus; DILE) is a side effect of antihypertensives, such as hydralazine and methyldopa. Other drugs that can lead to DILE include monoclonal TNF-α inhibitors, such as infliximab or etanercept, procainamide, penicillamine, isoniazid, minocycline, and phenytoin. Nitrates do not cause erectile dysfunction.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with exertional chest pain. The clinician prescribes sublingual nitroglycerin, which provides adequate symptom relief. Which of the following best explains how nitroglycerin alleviates this patient’s chest pain?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Nitrates, such as nitroglycerin, cause arterial and venous vasodilation by inducing smooth muscle relaxation. Anginal pain relief is mainly achieved by venous dilation (venous pooling), which leads to decreased end-diastolic pressure (i.e., decreased preload), reduced myocardial wall tension, and improved myocardial perfusion. The decreased preload results in reduced heart size and decreased myocardial oxygen demand. To a lesser degree, nitrates decrease afterload by triggering arterial vasodilation, thus reducing myocardial contraction effort and oxygen demand. Because the coronary arteries are already fully dilated in patients with CAD in an attempt to provide as much oxygen to cardiac tissue as possible, the effect of nitrates on these vessels is limited.
Image Description:

Exogenous nitrous oxide (NO) activates guanylyl cyclase, resulting in activation of protein kinase G. There is a reduction in intracellular calcium as a result of increased sarcoplasmic reticulum calcium ATPase (SERCA) and an increase in myosin-light-chain-phosphatase (MLCP) activity, resulting in smooth muscle relaxation. The net result of both pathways is vasodilation.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased atherosclerotic plaque stability is achieved with statins (e.g., atorvastatin, rosuvastatin). While this patient may benefit from statin therapy, this medication would not have any effect on his current chest pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased venous pooling can result from the use of compression stockings or sympathomimetic drugs that cause vasoconstriction of arteriolar and venous vasculature. This increases venous return and therefore cardiac preload, which in turn increases myocardial wall tension and reduces myocardial perfusion. Nitroglycerin has the opposite effect: smooth muscle relaxation, mainly of the venous vessels, leads to venodilation and subsequent increased blood pooling in the venous system.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased ventricular compliance occurs most commonly in ventricular hypertrophy (LVH or RVH) and any type of restrictive cardiomyopathy. Nitroglycerin actually improves ventricular compliance through reduced myocardial wall tension.

E) INCORRECT:

Peripheral arterial vasodilation is one of the effects of nitroglycerin. It results in decreased afterload, which in turn decreases myocardial oxygen demand to a certain extent. However, there is another, much more prominent nitroglycerin-mediated mechanism that is more likely to reduce this patient's symptoms. Arterial vasodilation is the primary effect of calcium channel blockers, not that of nitroglycerin.
questions.hint: This patient's exertional chest pain relieved by nitroglycerin indicates angina pectoris due to coronary artery disease (CAD), which is consistent with his history of risk factors (hypertension and diabetes mellitus).

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to your clinic with exertional chest pain. You prescribe sublingual nitroglycerin, which provides adequate symptom relief. Which one of the following best explains how nitroglycerin alleviates his chest pain?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Peripheral arterial vasodilation is one of the effects of nitroglycerin. It results in decreased afterload, which in turn decreases myocardial oxygen demand to a certain extent. However, there is another, much more prominent nitroglycerin-mediated mechanism that is more likely to reduce this patient's symptoms. Arterial vasodilation is the primary effect of calcium channel blockers, not that of nitroglycerin.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased ventricular compliance occurs most commonly in ventricular hypertrophy (LVH or RVH) and any type of restrictive cardiomyopathy. Nitroglycerin actually improves ventricular compliance through reduced myocardial wall tension.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased atherosclerotic plaque stability is achieved with statins (e.g., atorvastatin, rosuvastatin). While this patient may benefit from statin therapy, this medication would not have any effect on his current chest pain.

D) CORRECT:

Nitrates, such as nitroglycerin, cause arterial and venous vasodilation by inducing smooth muscle relaxation. Anginal pain relief is mainly achieved by venous dilation (venous pooling), which leads to decreased end-diastolic pressure (i.e., decreased preload), reduced myocardial wall tension, and improved myocardial perfusion. The decreased preload results in reduced heart size and decreased myocardial oxygen demand. To a lesser degree, nitrates decrease afterload by triggering arterial vasodilation, thus reducing myocardial contraction effort and oxygen demand. Because the coronary arteries are already fully dilated in patients with CAD in an attempt to provide as much oxygen to cardiac tissue as possible, the effect of nitrates on these vessels is limited.

Key learning point: Nitroglycerin relieves angina primarily by venous dilation, which decreases end-diastolic pressure (preload), reduces myocardial oxygen demand, and alleviates cardiac ischemia.
Image Description:

Exogenous nitrous oxide (NO) activates guanylyl cyclase, resulting in activation of protein kinase G. There is a reduction in intracellular calcium as a result of increased sarcoplasmic reticulum calcium ATPase (SERCA) and an increase in myosin-light-chain-phosphatase (MLCP) activity, resulting in smooth muscle relaxation. The net result of both pathways is vasodilation.

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased venous pooling can result from the use of compression stockings or sympathomimetic drugs that cause vasoconstriction of arteriolar and venous vasculature. This increases venous return and therefore cardiac preload, which in turn increases myocardial wall tension and reduces myocardial perfusion. Nitroglycerin has the opposite effect: smooth muscle relaxation, mainly of the venous vessels, leads to venodilation and subsequent increased blood pooling in the venous system.
questions.hint: This patient's exertional chest pain relieved by nitroglycerin indicates angina pectoris due to coronary artery disease (CAD), which is consistent with his history of risk factors (hypertension and diabetes mellitus).

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with hypertension and hyperlipidemia comes to your clinic with a 10-month history of substernal chest pain on exertion that is relieved with rest. His pulse is 82/min and blood pressure is 145/82 mm Hg. You prescribe isosorbide dinitrate. Which one of the following adverse effects is this patient most likely to experience as a result of this drug?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nonproductive cough is a side effect of ACE inhibitors. This side effect is due to decreased breakdown of bradykinin, which increases production of arachidonic acid metabolites (e.g., prostaglandins). The accumulation of prostaglandins in the upper respiratory tract and the lungs results in nonproductive cough. Nitrates do not cause cough.

B) INCORRECT:

Beta blockers can cause erectile dysfunction by reducing sympathetic activity and cardiac output, lowering penile blood flow. They may also decrease testosterone levels and cause central nervous system effects like fatigue and depression, all of which impair sexual function. Patients taking PDE-5 inhibitors for erectile dysfunction have an increased risk of life-threatening hypotension if nitrates are taken within 24 hours of a PDE-5 inhibitor. Nitrates do not cause erectile dysfunction.

C) INCORRECT:

Lupus-like syndrome (drug-induced lupus erythematosus; DILE) is a side effect of antihypertensives, such as hydralazine and methyldopa. Other drugs that can lead to DILE include monoclonal TNF-α inhibitors, such as infliximab or etanercept, procainamide, penicillamine, isoniazid, minocycline, and phenytoin. Nitrates do not cause DILE.

D) INCORRECT:

Digital vasospasm (secondary Raynaud phenomenon) is a potential side effect of beta blockers. This side effect is mediated by the blockade of β2-receptors, which causes vasoconstriction. Nitrates do not cause digital vasospasm.

E) CORRECT:

Headaches are a common side effect of nitrates and affect approximately 10% of patients. These headaches are either mild-to-moderate and occur immediately after drug administration (due to nitric oxide-induced vasodilation) or migraine-like, occurring several hours after drug intake (due to nitric oxide-mediated release of neurotransmitters such as calcitonin gene-related peptide and glutamate, and/or altered ion channel function). Nitrate-induced vasodilation decreases both preload and afterload and improves myocardial perfusion, but may also result in cutaneous flushing and hypotension. Other adverse effects include gastroesophageal reflux and reflex tachycardia, the latter of which can be treated with beta blockers.

Key learning point: Side effects of nitrates include headaches, cutaneous flushing, hypotension, and GERD.
questions.hint: Nitrates (e.g., isosorbide dinitrate) work by forming free radical nitric oxide, which leads to smooth muscle relaxation and vasodilation.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with coronary artery disease agrees to participate in a pharmacological study. He takes an oral medication that leads to dephosphorylation of myosin light chains in venous smooth muscle cells. An investigator measures the plasma concentration of the drug over time after intravenous and then after oral administration. There is no statistically significant difference in the dose-corrected area under the curve (AUC) for the two routes of administration. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this finding?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Bioavailability describes the rate and concentration at which the drug appears in circulation and is expressed as a percentage of the dose that was initially administered. In this case, oral administration of the drug shows no statistically significant difference in the dose-corrected AUC from intravenous administration, indicating that this drug has near 100% bioavailability. Isosorbide mononitrate is an oral medication that dephosphorylates myosin light chains in venous smooth muscle cells. Unlike some other nitrates, isosorbide mononitrate does not undergo first-pass metabolism by the liver and thus has approx. 100% bioavailability. An oral form of isosorbide mononitrate is available and is used in the treatment and prevention of angina pectoris due to coronary artery disease.
Image Description:

The blue line shows the concentration of a substance administered intravenously (IV) over a period of time, and the red line shows the concentration of a substance taken orally. The ratio of the area under the curve (AUC) of the orally administered substance to the AUC of the IV substance yields the bioavailability (F) of a substance.

B) INCORRECT:

If an orally administered drug were to undergo extensive first-pass metabolism, it would show a significantly reduced AUC relative to the AUC for an intravenously administered drug; the AUC for oral administration is not reduced. Nitroglycerine is an example of an oral medication that dephosphorylates myosin light chains in venous smooth muscle cells; however, it undergoes extensive first-pass metabolism.

C) INCORRECT:

Drugs with a low volume of distribution are often not lipophilic and therefore tend to be restricted to the intravascular compartment. However, the level of lipid permeability of a drug, as reflected by the volume of distribution, is specific to the drug itself and not to the route of administration. The volume of distribution is not relevant for the evaluation of the respective AUC when administering a drug orally versus intravenously, so it would not explain the similarity of these two AUCs.

D) INCORRECT:

Clearance is inversely proportional to the AUC; the more delayed the clearance of a drug is, the longer the drug stays in the body, and the higher the AUC is. Assuming that the same drug is being administered, the difference (or lack thereof) between the AUC for two different methods of administration would not be influenced by delayed clearance.

E) INCORRECT:

The length of a half-life varies based on the route of administration; a long half-life can extend the plasma concentration. However, a long half-life would not explain why two methods of administration of the same drug show no significant difference in their AUC. Moreover, half-life determines how quickly a drug is removed from the body; this investigator is studying the appearance of the drug in circulation.

F) INCORRECT:

Plasma-protein binding describes the affinity of a drug to bind to plasma proteins in instances where only the unbound fraction of the drug has a pharmacological effect. While strong plasma-protein binding can affect the distribution and clearance of a drug, it does not affect the AUC, even if the method of administration is different.
questions.hint: This drug is almost entirely absorbed into systemic circulation when orally administered, as indicated by the lack of difference in the dose-corrected AUCs for oral and intravenous administration.
